stories.title: Nika Uses Esper Hand by Esper Bionics

stories.text:
Hi all,

i run a sass application and i want to document some aspects of it as best as possible so it helps both my users and me. The app prepares various kinds of labels for e-commerce and mortar store owners to label their products. The users aren't super technical most of the time.

What are some good docs you know? Can you suggest some DOs and DONT's? Do you prefer some specific structure, search features, media usage, etc?

Thank you!
stories.title: Ask HN: How to Build Best Docs?

stories.text:
Stripe have beautiful book previews on their website - https://press.stripe.com/

I am sure I saw a link to an open source repo that helped you create your own in the same style - does anyone have the link?
stories.title: Ask HN: How can I generate book previews like Stripe Press?

stories.text:
Overall, my career looked pretty regular. Degree in CS, some internships as software developer, worked as data scientist for almost 3 years and lastly joined big company™ as service manager for a software development team (out of curiosity).

I find management quit appealing. I get along with the team & other managers pretty well, I find my routine enjoyable, etc.. But I got one concern: I always saw my developer skills as some kind of job insurance. To me it seems obvious that I will always be able to find a job, as long as I keep my dev skills up to date. Does this hold true if I stick to the management path or is my assumption just wrong? I am also involved in recruiting and I can see many managers in their 50s applying for roles such as Scrum Master or Product Owner. However, their applications are all turned down because they are way too expensive for such position.

In short: will I get in management in my 50s?
stories.title: Ask HN: Leaving Developer Position Behind
